questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of difficulty swallowing food. Initially, only solid food was problematic, but liquids have also become more difficult to swallow over the last 2 months. She also reports occasional regurgitation of food when she lies down. The patient is an avid bird-watcher and returned from a 3-week trip to the Amazon rainforest 3 months ago. She has had a 3.5-kg (7.7-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. She has not had abdominal pain, blood in her stools, or fever. She underwent an abdominal hysterectomy for fibroid uterus 6 years ago. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.2 g/dL. A barium esophagram is shown. Esophageal manometry monitoring shows the lower esophageal sphincter fails to relax during swallowing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the chest and abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral medications, such as calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine), are the least effective treatment option for achalasia and should only be considered when other treatment options are unsuccessful or contraindicated. Because this patient has not undergone any prior treatment for achalasia, nifedipine is not the most appropriate step in management at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin injections are highly effective for treating any type of achalasia in patients who cannot undergo definitive treatment. However, the effects are temporary, and over 50% of patients require repeat treatment within 6–12 months. Since this patient has not received further evaluation or prior therapy for achalasia, botulinum toxin injection is not the most appropriate step in management at this time

C) CORRECT:

Upper endoscopy is indicated in patients with features of achalasia to rule out pseudoachalasia, which is caused by an underlying condition, such as esophageal cancer. This patient's smoking history and significant weight loss raise concern for malignancy, necessitating endoscopic inspection. If esophageal cancer is suspected, endoscopic ultrasound and biopsy should also be performed. After pseudoachalasia is ruled out, pneumatic dilation, laparoscopic Heller myotomy, or peroral endoscopic myotomy may be used as definitive treatment depending on the subtype of achalasia. If definitive treatment is not possible, an injection of botulinum toxin may be used.

D) INCORRECT:

Giemsa staining can be used to detect Chagas disease, which may manifest with megaesophagus and features of achalasia. Although this patient recently traveled to a region where Chagas disease is endemic, her symptoms started before the trip, and features of achalasia typically occur during the chronic phase 10–20 years after primary infection. Therefore, Chagas disease is an unlikely cause of her condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic Heller myotomy is a surgical procedure used for the definitive treatment of achalasia. This procedure is often combined with fundoplication to reduce the postoperative risk of gastroesophageal reflux disease. However, before proceeding with definitive treatment, pseudoachalasia must be ruled out in all patients with suspected achalasia.

F) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the chest and abdomen is indicated in the diagnostic staging of gastroesophageal cancers. Given the patient's smoking history and significant weight loss, malignancy should be ruled out. However, a CT scan of the chest and abdomen is not the preferred modality for ruling out malignancy.
questions.hint: The combination of dysphagia to solids and liquids, bird-beak sign on esophagram, and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter on manometry are indicative of achalasia.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of intermittent dysphagia. He states that he drinks a lot of water during meals to help reduce the discomfort of swallowing food. He has hypertension and non-erosive gastroesophageal reflux disease. He has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily for 32 years. He does not drink alcohol. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and lansoprazole. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 101 kg (222 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. A barium esophagram shows a concentric filling defect at the distal esophagus. An upper endoscopy shows a sliding hiatal hernia and a constricting ring at the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsies from the lesion show squamocolumnar epithelium with no metaplasia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esophagectomy is mainly performed to treat esophageal cancer. Although this patient's dysphagia to solids and findings on barium esophagram are concerning for esophageal cancer, the findings on upper endoscopy and biopsy results are consistent with a Schatzki ring. Therefore, a less invasive treatment is preferred.
Image Description:

Barium esophagram (lateral view) of a patient with esophageal carcinoma

A long segment irregular stricture is seen in the mid third of the thoracic esophagus (green overlay). The superior aspect of the stricture has an apple-core appearance (indicated by dashed line).

B) INCORRECT:

An esophageal stent can be used for palliative treatment of an inoperable esophageal malignancy to allow for the passage of food and liquids. A stent may also be considered to treat refractory strictures. However, other treatment options are available and should first be tried in this patient.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

A newly placed self-expanding metal (nitinol) stent is visible. The stent holds the esophagus open as part of the palliative treatment for esophageal cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Intralesional application of corticosteroids can be used to treat Schatzki rings, but it is not the first-line treatment and is rather used for recurrent strictures.

Corticosteroids play a more important role in treating eosinophilic esophagitis, which can also manifest with dysphagia and esophageal rings. However, in eosinophilic esophagitis an endoscopy typically shows linear furrows, eosinophilic abscesses, and multiple esophageal rings, not just a singular constriction. Furthermore, eosinophilic esophagitis more commonly affects younger patients and numerous eosinophils are usually seen on biopsy.
Image Description:

Endoscopic image of the esophagus

Circumferential mucosal lesions (rings/corrugations; examples indicated by blue overlay) are visible.

Yellow lines: longitudinal furrows; Dashed encirclement: Z-line

D) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation is used to treat Plummer-Vinson syndrome, which also presents with dysphagia. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is associated with esophageal webs on upper endoscopy (which appear thin and membranous; different from the ring seen at the gastroesophageal junction in this patient) and symptoms of severe iron deficiency anemia (e.g., pallor, fatigue, weakness, dyspnea on exertion). This patient's presentation is more consistent with an esophageal ring and he has no features of iron deficiency anemia, therefore iron supplementation is not indicated at this time.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the esophagus

A thin, semilunar membrane (esophageal web; blue overlay) projects into the esophageal lumen. Esophageal webs usually occur in the upper esophagus and do not involve the muscle layer.

Cervical esophageal webs, iron deficiency anemia, and dysphagia form the classic triad of findings in Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has a hiatal hernia, Nissen fundoplication would further narrow the lower esophagus and worsen dysphagia. After treatment of the Schatzki ring, Nissen fundoplication may be considered for treating his sliding hiatal hernia.
Image Description:

Barium swallow, AP radiograph showing the contrast-enhanced esophagus (1), the herniated esophageal sphincter (arrow), the sliding hiatal hernia (2), and the stomach (3) with typical contour.

F) CORRECT:

Mechanical dilation with a bougie or balloon dilator is the first-line treatment for an obstructing Schatzki ring. This procedure provides immediate symptom relief. However, recurrence of strictures is possible and subsequent dilations may be needed. Esophageal rings are thought to arise secondary to chronic damage from gastroesophageal reflux disease.
Image Description:

Barium swallow (lateral view): circular narrowing of the esophagus directly at the esophagogastric junction (Schatzki ring or B-ring). As opposed to A-rings (which are located just proximal to the EG junction), B-rings often can only be seen if there is a concomitant hiatal hernia. with which they are frequently associated (as is the case here).
questions.hint: Dysphagia and circumferential esophageal narrowing, together with normal histology findings, are consistent with a Schatzki ring (esophageal ring).

questions.text: A previously healthy 57-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of acute retrosternal chest pain that radiates to his back. The pain started suddenly while he was having dinner. A few moments before the onset of the pain, he experienced discomfort when trying to eat or drink anything. On the way to the hospital, he took a sublingual nitrate tablet that he had at home, which helped relieve the pain. His pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 144/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm with no ST-segment abnormalities. An esophagogram shows areas of diffuse, uncoordinated spasms in several segments along the length of the esophagus. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Simultaneous multi-peak contractions on esophageal manometry
High lower esophageal sphincter pressure on esophageal manometry
Mass at the gastroesophageal junction on ultrasonography
Elevated CK-MB levels on serum studies
Significant ST-segment depression on exercise stress test

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Simultaneous multi-peak contractions on esophageal manometry are the characteristic finding of DES. Repetitive nonperistaltic, nonprogressive contractions impede the progression of solid and liquid foods down the esophagus, which classically leads to dysphagia and squeezing retrosternal chest pain, as seen in this patient. Symptoms and relieving factors (nitrates) of DES can closely resemble those of cardiac pathology. Therefore, acute coronary syndrome should always be ruled out before considering a gastrointestinal disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Multiple mucosal erosions on endoscopy are consistent with reflux esophagitis caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). This condition can cause retrosternal pain that radiates to the back and, in some cases, dysphagia as seen in this patient. However, additional symptoms like regurgitation and nausea would also be present. Furthermore, in GERD, esophagogram may show strictures, ulcers, and gastric hernias due to gastroesophageal reflux, whereas the multiple areas of diffuse, uncoordinated spasms with segmentation seen in this patient are more consistent with DES.

C) INCORRECT:

High lower esophageal sphincter pressure on esophageal manometry is diagnostic of achalasia, which presents with progressive difficulty swallowing, retrosternal chest pain, and a foreign body sensation in the esophagus. However, this patient's sudden onset of symptoms while eating is not typical for achalasia. Also, the esophagogram findings in this patient are more consistent with DES.

D) INCORRECT:

A mass at the gastroesophageal junction on ultrasonography is suspicious for esophageal cancer. Patients typically present with dysphagia (for solids at first and liquids later), regurgitation, and systemic manifestations such as weight loss, fatigue, and anemia. This patient does not have systemic manifestations and esophagogram findings are more consistent with DES than esophageal cancer. If a mass were present, it would be seen as a narrowed asymmetrical lumen in the lower esophagus on esophagogram.

E) INCORRECT:

Elevated CK-MB levels on serum studies are consistent with myocardial infarction. Although this patient has retrosternal chest pain radiating to the back, he lacks other symptoms like dyspnea, palpitations, diaphoresis, and typical findings on ECG. Furthermore, esophagogram results are consistent with DES.

F) INCORRECT:

Cardiac exercise stress test is used for diagnosis and prognosis of patients with anginal symptoms. If the patient has coronary artery disease (CAD), the atherosclerotic plaque would prevent sufficient blood required to meet the increased oxygen requirements from reaching the myocardium and thus show ST-segment depression on ECG. Although retrosternal chest pain that radiates to the back and is relieved with nitrates could be caused by CAD, such events would be independent of eating or drinking and more likely be triggered by exertion. Additionally, other features like palpitations, sweating, and dyspnea would likely also be present. CAD would not explain this patient's esophagogram results, which indicate DES.

G) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive contractions on esophageal manometry are consistent with hypertension peristalsis (nutcracker esophagus). Although this patient's chest pain while eating could suggest this diagnosis, the presence of diffuse, uncoordinated spasms with segmentation on esophagogram are more consistent with DES.
questions.hint: This patient has dysphagia to solids and liquids and his esophagogram shows a corkscrew or rosary bead appearance. These findings are suggestive of distal esophageal spasm (DES).

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of worsening difficulty swallowing food and retrosternal chest discomfort. She reports that she sometimes has a feeling of “food getting stuck” in her throat and hears a “gurgling sound” from her throat while eating. She says that she occasionally coughs up pieces of undigested food. She has noticed a bad taste in her mouth and bad breath. She has not had fever or weight loss. She has been visiting Mexico every year for the past 7 years. She has Raynaud disease treated with nifedipine. Her father died because of gastric cancer. She smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but stopped 25 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9800/mm3, and platelet count is 215,000/mm3. ECG shows sinus rhythm with no evidence of ischemia. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

ZD is a false diverticulum (herniation of mucosa and submucosa only) that typically herniates through the Killian triangle at the dorsal hypopharynx. The best confirmatory test in patients with ZD is barium esophagram with dynamic continuous fluoroscopy. The characteristic outpouching in the posterior pharyngoesophageal wall confirms the diagnosis.

Patients presenting with symptomatic ZD should undergo open surgical or endoscopic treatment.
Image Description:

Barium swallow

The contrast-enhanced mass in the upper esophagus is most likely a Zenker diverticulum.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry is useful to identify esophageal motility disorders, such as achalasia. This patient presents with some typical features of achalasia including dysphagia and regurgitation. However, achalasia often causes weight loss, which is not the case here, and it would not explain the bubbling sounds while eating. Esophageal manometry is also useful for detecting esophageal involvement in systemic sclerosis (SSc), which often manifests with Raynaud disease, as seen here. The absence of other characteristic findings of SSc, such as thickening and hardening of the skin or sclerodactyly, however, makes this diagnosis less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the neck is indicated in the diagnostic staging of esophageal cancers. This patient's dysphagia and regurgitation could be symptoms of an esophageal tumor, for which her smoking history and family history are risk factors. However, the absence of weight loss and anemia, together with the gurgling sound this patient hears while eating, is more suggestive of a different diagnosis. Also, a CT scan of the neck and chest would not be the confirmatory test in the diagnosis of esophageal cancers. Larger outpouchings can be an incidental finding on CT scans of some individuals with ZD. However, a CT scan is not routinely used to confirm or exclude this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Serology and PCR can be used to detect Trypanosoma cruzi, the pathogen that causes Chagas disease. Chagas disease may present with achalasia (megaesophagus), which typically leads to dysphagia and regurgitation, as seen in this patient. This patient's visits to Mexico, which is endemic for Chagas disease, increase her risk for this condition. However, megaesophagus typically occurs in the chronic phase of Chagas disease (approx. after 10–20 years), which is inconsistent with her travel history. Moreover, the chronic phase of Chagas disease would usually manifest with other symptoms including arrhythmias due to cardiomyopathy (ECG shows no abnormalities) and/or abdominal complaints due to involvement of the gastrointestinal tract, neither of which is the case here.

E) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy is used for the diagnosis of various esophageal conditions including esophageal cancer. This patient's dysphagia and regurgitation could be symptoms of an esophageal tumor, for which her smoking history and family history are risk factors. However, the absence of weight loss and anemia, together with the gurgling sound this patient hears while eating, is more suggestive of a different diagnosis. Upper endoscopy of the esophagus can be used for the detection of diverticula, such as ZD. However, it is not the most sensitive diagnostic method for this condition and may lead to small openings in the esophageal wall being missed.

F) INCORRECT:

Esophageal pH monitoring is used to confirm the diagnosis of nonerosive reflux disease (NERD), which may also manifest with regurgitation and dysphagia, as seen in this patient. However, the absence of typical features of NERD such as retrosternal burning pain with meals, chronic nonproductive cough, and/or nocturnal cough make ZD a more likely diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic ultrasound of the esophagus is used in the staging of esophageal cancer to determine tumor infiltration depth and register regional lymph node disease. This patient's dysphagia and regurgitation could be symptoms of an esophageal tumor, for which her smoking history and family history are risk factors. However, the absence of weight loss and anemia, together with the gurgling sound this patient hears while eating, is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: The patient's symptoms of dysphagia, halitosis, regurgitation, and coughing up of undigested food as well as her retrosternal pressure and the gurgling sound while eating are most likely caused by symptomatic Zenker diverticulum (ZD).

questions.text: A 73-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss over the last month. During this time he has not been able to eat more than one bite without coughing immediately and sometimes he regurgitates food through his nose. His symptoms are worse with liquids. One month ago he had a stroke in the right middle cerebral artery. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include aspirin, amlodipine, metformin, and simvastatin. Examination of the oropharynx, chest, and abdomen shows no abnormalities. Neurological examination shows facial drooping on the left and decreased strength in the left upper and lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A videofluoroscopic modified barium swallow is considered the test of choice for evaluating oropharyngeal dysphagia. It involves direct visualization of the entire swallowing process using continuous x-rays and barium contrast. This diagnostic test evaluates the patient's risk of aspiration and determines whether the patient might benefit from supervised feedings, swallow rehabilitation therapy, and/or enteral nutrition.
Image Description:

Videofluoroscopy of the neck (lateral view)

The video shows the oral preparatory and propulsive stages followed by the pharyngeal and esophageal stages. No abnormalities are noted.

B) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the neck is used as part of the staging process for esophageal cancer. While esophageal cancer can also present with weight loss and dysphagia, this patient developed dysphagia early in the swallowing process, coughing, and nasal regurgitation after a recent stroke, which is indicative of a neuromuscular cause of his symptoms. Furthermore, a staging CT is only indicated after confirmation of esophageal cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophagram via barium swallow classically involves ingestion of barium contrast and acquisition of a single static x-ray image as contrast enters the stomach. Barium swallow is indicated in patients with esophageal dysphagia, most commonly after an upper endoscopy is unrevealing. This patient presents with oropharyngeal, rather than esophageal, dysphagia. A standard barium swallow does not evaluate the oropharynx and is therefore not the preferred initial diagnostic test for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry is indicated in patients with esophageal dysphagia who are believed to have an esophageal motility disorder. Because this patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with oropharyngeal dysphagia than esophageal dysphagia, esophageal manometry is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Transnasal laryngoscopy can be used to visualize the oropharynx, to assess pharyngeal swallowing, and especially to assess possible aspiration and retention of food in the pharynx after swallowing (fiberoptic endoscopic examination of swallowing). However, it is not the preferred initial test as it does not allow visualization of the food bolus beyond the oropharynx.

F) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy is the appropriate step in management for most patients that present with esophageal dysphagia and/or odynophagia as it can be both diagnostic and therapeutic. Unlike this patient, who reports swallowing problems immediately after taking a bite, patients with esophageal dysphagia report food “getting stuck” in their chest and do not have difficulty initiating swallowing. Upper endoscopy is not the initial test of choice for this patient with suspected oropharyngeal dysphagia.
questions.hint: Dysphagia early in the swallowing process that worsens with liquids, coughing, and nasal regurgitation indicate oropharyngeal dysphagia. Oropharyngeal dysphagia commonly affects patients with neuromuscular dysfunction, such as this patient who recently had a stroke.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man presents with symptoms of dysphagia that have been getting progressively worse for the past 5 years. The symptoms are predominantly associated with solid foods. He sometimes notices a gurgling sensation in the back of his throat and sometimes coughs up undigested food and pills. He reports a sore throat and raspy voice. He denies any weight loss, hemoptysis, or significant pain.
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hiatal hernia, scleroderma of the esophagus, and gastroesophageal reflux disease may be risk factors for dysphagia, but regurgitation of digested food is the usual presentation for these conditions, and oropharyngeal dysphagia would be rare.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal cancer is an unlikely cause of such long-standing symptoms but should always be considered and evaluated in a patient with progressive dysphagia.

C) CORRECT:

Zenker diverticulum is typically seen after age 70 and usually in men. The most common presentation is dysphagia. Typically, patients describe regurgitation of undigested food, bad breath, a gurgling sensation in the throat, and hoarseness. The etiology is thought to be weakness in the pharyngeal wall above the upper esophageal sphincter, due to poor compliance of the upper esophageal sphincter. The presence of sore throat and a raspy voice suggest oropharyngeal dysphagia. See “Overview of oropharyngeal dysphagia” table.

Key learning point: A common cause of long-standing dysphagia, throat gurgling, and regurgitation of undigested food and pills in an older adult is Zenker diverticulum.

D) INCORRECT:

Hiatal hernia, scleroderma of the esophagus, and gastroesophageal reflux disease may be risk factors for dysphagia, but regurgitation of digested food is the usual presentation for these conditions, and oropharyngeal dysphagia would be rare.

E) INCORRECT:

Achalasia is associated with regurgitation of undigested food and a gurgling sensation in the throat, but it is also usually accompanied by weight loss and would not typically manifest for the first time in older age.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with obesity, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, type 2 diabetes, and a 35-pack-year history of cigarette smoking presents for evaluation of progressive difficulty with swallowing. He describes dysphagia to solid foods that has progressively worsened during the past 2 to 3 months. He initially modified his diet but now has difficulty swallowing liquids as well. He reports that anything that he takes by mouth “gets stuck” in his chest, leading to regurgitation and choking episodes. He reports no chest pain, fever, or heartburn. He has lost 8.2 kg since his last visit one year ago.
Which one of the following tests should this patient undergo now?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esophageal pH testing is useful in the evaluation of suspected gastroesophageal reflux disease, including the evaluation of atypical chest pain; however, it is not a first-line test in patients with esophageal dysphagia, as malignancy must be ruled out first.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry is used to evaluate for esophageal motility disorders (such as achalasia) and may eventually be considered in this patient if there is no evidence of a structural cause for his symptoms on another initial test.

C) INCORRECT:

A modified barium swallow study is used to evaluate oropharyngeal dysphagia. Oropharyngeal dysphagia may occur with liquids or solids and may lead to aspiration. In contrast, esophageal dysphagia is often characterized by the feeling that solids are “stuck” in the chest area. Given the localization of this patient’s symptoms to the chest rather than the neck, esophageal dysphagia is more likely than oropharyngeal dysphagia

D) INCORRECT:

A barium swallow study, or barium esophagram, can be used to evaluate esophageal dysphagia and can provide a general sense of both the structure and motility of the esophagus. However, this patient has symptoms of progressive esophageal dysphagia, a history of smoking, and recent weight loss, thereby heightening the concern for esophageal cancer. Of note, a barium swallow study may be better at diagnosing a Zenker diverticulum in the proximal esophagus, which can cause oropharyngeal dysphagia and food regurgitation, but in this patient, malignancy should be excluded first.

E) CORRECT:

Esophageal cancer is the primary diagnosis to exclude in this patient.

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is the best initial test, as it allows for direct visualization, tissue biopsy, and potential therapy, including hemostasis and stenting. EGD can also detect other causes of dysphagia, including esophagitis, esophageal strictures, and rings, but these conditions are less likely to cause weight loss unless the patient’s oral intake is significantly reduced.

Key learning point: A middle-aged patient with progressive dysphagia, weight loss, and a history of cigarette smoking should be evaluated with esophagogastroduodenoscopy.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents with six months of progressive difficulty swallowing both liquids and solids. He frequently regurgitates undigested food, noticing partial relief afterward, and has occasional nocturnal cough but denies heartburn. He has no significant weight loss. Physical examination is normal. Basic laboratory tests are within normal limits. A plain chest radiograph is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study?

choices.text: CT scan of the chest with intravenous contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A videofluoroscopic swallow study evaluates the oropharyngeal phase of swallowing, useful in suspected oropharyngeal dysphagia. It visualizes bolus formation and pharyngeal transit. This patient’s symptoms of progressive dysphagia and regurgitation suggest an esophageal disorder, not oropharyngeal dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan with contrast identifies structural abnormalities like masses or lymphadenopathy. It is beneficial when malignancy or extrinsic esophageal compression is suspected. This patient’s symptoms and normal chest radiograph suggest a motility disorder, not an obstructive lesion, making CT less appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

24-hour esophageal pH monitoring assesses acid reflux in suspected gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) by quantifying esophageal acid exposure. It is most useful when symptoms like heartburn or acid regurgitation are present. This patient’s symptoms suggest an esophageal motility disorder rather than GERD, making pH monitoring inappropriate.

D) CORRECT:

An upper gastrointestinal barium swallow is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study for evaluating dysphagia involving both liquids and solids, especially with regurgitation of undigested food. This imaging technique provides a dynamic assessment of the swallowing mechanism and can identify structural abnormalities such as diverticula or strictures. It is sensitive in detecting esophageal motility disorders and anatomic changes, making it valuable before more invasive studies. The pattern of dysphagia and regurgitation observed on a barium study guides further management and specialized testing.

Key learning point: An upper GI barium study is useful for diagnosing motility disorders, obstructions, or anatomical abnormalities in the upper GI tract, especially when symptoms suggest relief by vomiting.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to your clinic with an 8-month history of progressively worsening difficulty swallowing food. She reports occasionally feeling as though food is “getting stuck” in her throat and sometimes hears a “gurgling sound” from her throat while eating. She also occasionally coughs up pieces of undigested food. She has noticed a bad taste in her mouth and bad breath. She has not experienced any weight loss. Laboratory studies are within reference ranges. Which one of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

ZD is a false diverticulum (herniation of mucosa and submucosa only) that typically herniates through the Killian triangle at the dorsal hypopharynx. The best confirmatory test in patients with ZD is barium esophagram with dynamic continuous fluoroscopy. The characteristic outpouching in the posterior pharyngoesophageal wall confirms the diagnosis.

Patients presenting with symptomatic ZD should undergo open surgical or endoscopic treatment.

Key learning point: Barium esophagram with dynamic fluoroscopy is the most sensitive and confirmatory test for diagnosing Zenker diverticulum.
Image Description:

Barium swallow

The contrast-enhanced mass in the upper esophagus is most likely a Zenker diverticulum.

B) INCORRECT:

Upper endoscopy is used for the diagnosis of various esophageal conditions including esophageal cancer. This patient's dysphagia and regurgitation could be symptoms of an esophageal tumor. However, the absence of weight loss and anemia, together with the gurgling sound this patient hears while eating, is more suggestive of a different diagnosis. Upper endoscopy of the esophagus can be used for the detection of diverticula, such as ZD. However, it is not the most sensitive diagnostic method for this condition and may lead to small openings in the esophageal wall being missed.

C) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the neck is indicated in the diagnostic staging of esophageal cancers. This patient's dysphagia and regurgitation could be symptoms of an esophageal tumor. However, the absence of weight loss and anemia, together with the gurgling sound this patient hears while eating, is more suggestive of a different diagnosis. Also, a CT scan of the neck and chest would not be the confirmatory test in the diagnosis of esophageal cancers. Larger outpouchings can be an incidental finding on CT scans of some individuals with ZD. However, a CT scan is not routinely used to confirm or exclude this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Esophageal manometry is useful to identify esophageal motility disorders, such as achalasia. This patient presents with some typical features of achalasia including dysphagia and regurgitation. However, achalasia often causes weight loss, which is not the case here, and it would not explain the bubbling sounds while eating.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophageal pH monitoring is used to confirm the diagnosis of nonerosive reflux disease (NERD), which may also manifest with regurgitation and dysphagia, as seen in this patient. However, the absence of typical features of NERD such as retrosternal burning pain with meals, chronic nonproductive cough, and/or nocturnal cough make ZD a more likely diagnosis.
questions.hint: The patient's symptoms of dysphagia, halitosis, regurgitation, and coughing up of undigested food as well as the gurgling sound while eating are most likely caused by symptomatic Zenker diverticulum (ZD).

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of stroke 3 months ago presents with difficulty swallowing that began 2 weeks after discharge from rehabilitation. His wife reports he coughs frequently during meals and has had two episodes of fever with productive cough in the past month. The patient's voice sounds hoarse and wet after drinking water. He requires multiple attempts to initiate swallowing and has lost 8 pounds. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While chest CT may show pneumonia or aspiration changes, it cannot evaluate the underlying swallowing dysfunction that needs to be addressed. The priority is assessing swallowing function and aspiration risk.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has oropharyngeal dysphagia, evidenced by difficulty initiating swallowing, coughing during meals, wet voice, and recent history of likely aspiration pneumonia. Modified barium swallow is the preferred test for suspected oropharyngeal dysphagia, as it provides functional evaluation of swallowing and assesses aspiration risk.

C) INCORRECT:

High-resolution esophageal manometry is used to diagnose esophageal motility disorders after structural causes have been ruled out. This patient's immediate difficulty with swallowing initiation and aspiration symptoms suggest oropharyngeal rather than esophageal dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Empirical proton pump inhibitor therapy is considered for younger patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease symptoms and no red flags. This patient has signs of oropharyngeal dysfunction and aspiration risk, which call for immediate functional assessment.

E) INCORRECT:

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is the preferred initial test for esophageal dysphagia, but this patient's presentation suggests oropharyngeal dysphagia. EGD does not evaluate the oropharyngeal swallowing mechanism or aspiration risk.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a 35-pack-year smoking history presents with a 6-week history of progressive dysphagia. He initially had difficulty with large pieces of steak but now experiences symptoms with soft foods and liquids. He denies heartburn, regurgitation, or odynophagia. Physical examination shows no lymphadenopathy or thyromegaly. His weight has decreased from 180 to 170 pounds over the past 2 months. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Four-week trial of proton pump inhibitor therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Esophageal barium swallow may be considered as an initial test in specific circumstances, such as suspected stricture with high perforation risk when direct visualization is contraindicated. However, it is not the preferred initial test for most patients with esophageal dysphagia and red flags for malignancy.

B) INCORRECT:

High-resolution esophageal manometry is the gold standard for diagnosing esophageal motility disorders. However, it should only be performed after structural and inflammatory lesions have been ruled out. This patient has red flags that necessitate a more urgent diagnostic approach.

C) INCORRECT:

A trial of proton pump inhibitor therapy may be considered in patients under 50 years of age with characteristic features of GERD and no red flag features for malignancy. This patient is over 50 and has multiple red flags, including weight loss and rapid progression, necessitating a more urgent diagnostic approach.

D) INCORRECT:

Modified barium swallow is the appropriate initial test for oropharyngeal dysphagia, which typically manifests with difficulty initiating swallowing, coughing, or choking. This patient's symptoms of progressive difficulty with solids progressing to liquids are characteristic of esophageal dysphagia and raise suspicion for an underlying structural disorder, including malignancy.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is the most appropriate initial test for this patient with esophageal dysphagia who has multiple red flags for malignancy. Red flags include age over 50 years, unintentional weight loss, and rapid symptom progression over 6 weeks. EGD allows direct visualization of mucosal lesions and the ability to obtain biopsies if needed.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man is evaluated at a skilled nursing facility for persistent dysphagia 4 weeks after an ischemic stroke. He has a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation. Despite working with speech therapy, he has experienced a 5 kg weight loss over the past month. A recent video swallow study confirmed severe oropharyngeal dysphagia with silent aspiration of both thin liquids and pureed solids. Physical examination reveals cachexia and dry mucous membranes. He is afebrile with stable vital signs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's nutritional needs?

choices.text: Insertion of a nasogastric tube for enteral feeding
Intensify swallow rehabilitation therapy as the sole intervention
Continue a pureed diet with honey-thick liquids
Initiation of total parenteral nutrition via a central line
Placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nasogastric (NG) tube feeding is a reasonable option for short-term nutritional support, typically for less than 4 weeks. Given that this patient's dysphagia has already persisted for a month, a more durable, long-term solution is indicated. Long-term NG tube use is associated with patient discomfort, tube dislodgement, sinusitis, and potential interference with swallowing rehabilitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Swallow rehabilitation therapy is a critical component of this patient's long-term recovery and should be continued. However, it is not a nutritional intervention and will not resolve his immediate malnutrition and dehydration. Relying on therapy alone is unsafe, as he requires a secure method of nutritional support while he works towards recovering his swallowing function.

C) INCORRECT:

This dietary modification might be considered for a patient with milder dysphagia. However, the video swallow study has objectively demonstrated that this patient is aspirating even pureed solids. Continuing this diet would fail to provide adequate nutrition, as evidenced by his ongoing weight loss, and would place him at high risk for developing aspiration pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is reserved for patients with a non-functional or inaccessible gastrointestinal tract, such as in cases of prolonged ileus, bowel obstruction, or severe malabsorption. This patient's dysphagia is a swallowing problem, not a digestive one, so his gut is functional. TPN carries significant risks, including central line-associated bloodstream infections, liver dysfunction, and metabolic derangements.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has severe, persistent oropharyngeal dysphagia with confirmed aspiration and evidence of malnutrition (weight loss, cachexia). When enteral nutrition is anticipated for more than 4 weeks, a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube is the preferred method. It provides a secure, long-term route for nutrition, hydration, and medication administration, directly bypassing the compromised oropharynx. This intervention reduces the risk of aspiration pneumonia compared to continued oral feeding attempts. Since the patient's gastrointestinal tract is functional, enteral feeding is superior to parenteral nutrition due to lower risks of infection and metabolic complications, while also helping to maintain gut integrity.
questions.hint: This patient's dysphagia has persisted for four weeks and is causing significant malnutrition, indicating the need for a long-term nutritional solution.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 4-month history of progressive dysphagia, primarily with solid foods. He reports an unintentional 4.5-kg (10lb) weight loss. He has a long-standing history of poorly controlled gastroesophageal reflux disease, which he self-manages with intermittent antacids. His vital signs are normal. Physical examination is unremarkable. An upper endoscopy shows a short, circumferential narrowing in the distal esophagus. Biopsies taken from the area show squamous mucosa with inflammatory changes and fibrosis, with no evidence of malignancy or eosinophilic infiltration. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Repeat endoscopy with biopsy in 3 months
Placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy tube
Initiate high-dose proton pump inhibitor therapy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The primary treatment for the mechanical obstruction and dysphagia is endoscopic balloon dilation. This procedure involves passing a balloon catheter through the endoscope and inflating it within the stricture to stretch and widen the esophageal lumen, thereby relieving the patient's symptoms. Although medical management of the underlying GERD with a proton pump inhibitor is essential to prevent recurrence, it will not reverse the established fibrosis. Dilation is the necessary first step to address the existing obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

A repeat endoscopy would be appropriate for surveillance if a premalignant condition such as Barrett esophagus were found or if the initial biopsies were inconclusive. In this case, the biopsies have already confirmed a benign process and ruled out malignancy. Simply observing a symptomatic patient with dysphagia and weight loss would be inappropriate, as intervention is needed.

C) INCORRECT:

A percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube provides long-term enteral nutrition for patients who cannot swallow safely or adequately. Although this patient has weight loss, his obstruction is considered treatable. A PEG tube bypasses the problem rather than correcting it and is reserved for cases in which the obstruction cannot be relieved or is expected to be long-lasting.

D) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy is a critical component of managing a peptic stricture, as it treats the underlying GERD and reduces the risk of recurrence after dilation. However, PPIs alone do not resolve the established fibrotic narrowing that is causing the patient's mechanical dysphagia and weight loss. An intervention to open the stricture is required first.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection is considered for esophageal strictures that are very long, complex, or refractory to multiple attempts at endoscopic dilation. For a short, benign stricture that has not yet been treated, surgery is overly invasive.
questions.hint: This patient has a symptomatic benign peptic stricture, a complication of chronic, poorly controlled gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
